channel.title: Someone invite me to BitCoinMarket
channel.description: Also, tell me what it's like dealing with bit coins. Replies in pictorial format are accepted.

item.title: Someone invite me to BitCoinMarket
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

bitmarket.eu has been brilliant for me.

Read full topic

item.title: Someone invite me to BitCoinMarket
item.dc:creator: @nade nade
item.description:
@nade wrote:

That’s what I heard too, you can, for the sake of the example: split your Bit Coins among a bunch of new wallets. Which makes it significantly harder for law enforcement to figure out that you are using all addresses.

Also, why the fuck is it so complicated to get BitCoins? I have to sign up at LibertyExchange, then sign up at another site to buy LR(?) to put them into my account to go back to the BitCoin website to buy BitCoins and send them to someone else. Fuck.

Read full topic

item.title: Someone invite me to BitCoinMarket
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:7, topic:406362”][quote]He explains that because all Bitcoin transactions are recorded in a public log, though the identities of all the parties are anonymous, law enforcement could use sophisticated network analysis techniques to parse the transaction flow and track down individual Bitcoin users.

“Attempting major illicit transactions with bitcoin, given existing statistical analysis techniques deployed in the field by law enforcement, is pretty damned dumb,” he says.[/quote]
Jeff Garzik - Bitcoin Core Development[/quote]

I’ve heard about the pseudoanonymity of the Bitcoin system, but I still don’t understand how it’s practically possible. I thought if I changed my Bitcoin address for every transaction that there’s no way to track me down. Oh well, better trust the experts.

Read full topic

item.title: Someone invite me to BitCoinMarket
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

He explains that because all Bitcoin transactions are recorded in a public log, though the identities of all the parties are anonymous, law enforcement could use sophisticated network analysis techniques to parse the transaction flow and track down individual Bitcoin users.

“Attempting major illicit transactions with bitcoin, given existing statistical analysis techniques deployed in the field by law enforcement, is pretty damned dumb,” he says.


Jeff Garzik - Bitcoin Core Development

Read full topic

item.title: Someone invite me to BitCoinMarket
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

the bank:

No but seriously its not as safe as you think and there will be a big crash on the whole illicit side of the bit coins market. Don’t risk it right now.

Why do you think so?
